title: Heart key for cymon's mini geared heart

description.text:
A google sketchup file of cymon's awesome keyed heart gears keychain key.  Someone smarter than me can use it to print the key at a higher infill, separate to the gears, which they might choose to print at a lower infill.  
I printed my original plate at 30% (I think) infill, and the resultant key wasn't up to the task, although the gears printed with a high degree of awesomeness.

ATM I don't know how to export STL's from google sketchup basic, and I don't have the $ for pro, so it's an .skb atm.  Any ideas how to export as an .stl would be great. 
pro tip: cymon's original heart gear plate has 42332 polygons, apparently that's alot.

title: Improved Dial Knob for Prusa i3 MK2/MK3

description.text:
I find the factory dial knob on the Original Prusa i3 MK3 printer a bit tiny and awkward to fiddle around with. So I set out to design a "better" and more ergonomic one. I was inspired by the serrated dial knobs often found on vintage electronic appliances.

This knob not only has serrations which make it easier to grab and turn, but also has a chamfered edge to make it more comfortable to touch. It has a depression on top like the original so that it's easy to push down.

While the knob was designed for the Prusa printer, it can be used as a generic dial for any potentiometer with a 6mm diameter shaft.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Despite having the hole for the shaft on the bottom side of the print, I was able to print the model just fine without the need for any support for bridging the 6mm hole.

Assembly

Remove the original dial by carefully using a plastic ruler or similar tool as a lever.

Then push the new knob firmly onto the shaft of the potentiometer.

Post-Processing (Optional)

The knob (specfically, the depression) might benefit from some sanding and a subsequent coat of paint.

My Prusa MK3 came in black, and I think that a knob in silver actually suits it quite well :)

This is a replacement for the Marshall Major II part that easily breaks.
The steps for mounting it are as follows:
First take appart the two parts that form the original hinge(this may require quite a lot of pressure, but don't worry about breaking it, although you are going to need the small one that has two rubber pieces, it is not likely that it breaks). Then put the metal frame that holds the headphone in the printed part and mount the small piece aforementioned as it was on the original hinge and assemble the headphones together.
I hope that it works well for you!
After printing using PLA I dipped the piece in chloroform in order to get the shiny finnish seen in the pictures, however i don't think it is necessary.

To make this design I started with the design by MaCo117 listed in the remixed from section, and using it as a template I made my own design so I could use the small piece of the original hinge and I did not have to glue two pieces together.

title: Samsung Galaxy S7 Dashboard mount for Opel Zafira

description.text:
I needed a mount for my phone right behind the steering wheel. The place where I always have it in plain sight without blocking the view.

Be aware that the temperature will get high on the dashboard. I printed it with ABS to withstand the heat and because of it strength when clipping the phone.

I have placed a smaller piece of anti-slip mat between the dashboard and the mount to protect the dashboard from possible scratches and to prevent the mount from moving. Better safe than sorry.

Measure the shape of the dashboard

I guess these steps are quite familiar for most of you.

First I measured the shape of the dashboard with this little tool and scanned it with a simple flatbed scanner. The scanner makes sure you get a nice orthogonal view of the shape.

Next I used Paint.Net to create 2D basic shape.

The dashboard countour scanned and with overlay of the basic 2D shape. Improve the design in 5 steps

In 5 steps I created the design of the mount. Each step allowing to focus on a specific part and verify the results.

See the image of the steps:

  1. top-left; the shape from Paint.Net extruded to check that the design is correctly following the contour of the dashboard
  2. top-right; strengthened design
  3. bottom-left; extended to follow the dashboard top and added the clip for the phone
  4. bottom-right; modified the dashboard top, moved the phone up so it's above the steering wheel.
4 Intermediate steps

title: Valify V2 Robot Lawn Mower (concept body - under construction)

description.text:
So after printing some parts for Valify I realized, first of all, it looked like any lawnmower out there. So I had to go back to the drawing board and start from scratch. I wanted a unique look that looked fresh and futuristic. I also took some experience from the previous one and made improvements. This is Valify V2.

Chassis and body are now separated. Body are is only a "nice" cover on top of the actually robot.

Some parts are still not ready

  1. Solarpanel holder for lid
  2. Frontspoiler

Parts thats are user spefic are not included, this includes

  1. Wheels
  2. Motor mounts

Features I’m looking for:
1.No perimeter wire.
2.Different driving styles (diagonal cut, pattern cut etc..)
3.3D mapping. Creates a 3D map of the the garden.
4.Know exactly where the robot is in the garden.
5.Automatic raising of mower blades if they moves too Heavy (if to low height is set.)
6.Using a camera to recognize grasses and colors.

So with this wish list I came up with the following hardware specs for this build
Jetson TX2 Development Kit
Scanse Sweep
Intel® RealSense™ Camera ZR300
2x DC Planetary Geared Motor 24 Volt med Hall IC 30-33 RPM 8mm
2x Vapex Li-Po Battery 6S 22.2V 4000mAh 25C XT60
SparkFun 9DoF
RoboClaw 2x45A ST
Emlid Reach — RTK GNSS modules
(Mower motors for the blades I have not decided yet.)

Status
2018-02-21
-Working on Nose, Solar panel holder and some minor modification on some parts to minimize the need of support.

Updated parts: hjulhus hö, hjulhus vä. Replacement part hjulhus hö_1.1 and hjulhus vä_1.1. Update to minimize the need of support. saving 20h in total print time and around 500g filament (in my setup)

2018-02-23
Updated parts hjulhus hö_1.1 and hjulhus vä_1.1. Added radius on corners to avoid to tension when printing.

description.text:
Since I had my spool laying on the bottom of my printer and the filament was always twisting and curling, I looked on thingiverse for a simple tabletop spool holder and couldn't find any that would be useful to me. I'm sharing this model I made in case anyone needs it and doesn't have many tools around.
The model is to be printed in two copies, one for each side. To join both sides I used a 25mm diameter PVC pipe I had laying arround - with a 25,3mm designed hole the pipe slips right into place. The part was dimensioned to fit a 220mm diameter spool.
Since I didn't want the spool tipping in the middle of the print I decided to close the support on top. That might difficult the spool change but it definitely holds it in place as expected.

Printer:

Custom CoreXY

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,3mm Layer height

Infill:

Cubic, 5%

Notes:
  • ABS, Extruder @240°C, heat bed @100°C with enclosure;
  • Printed standing to avoid possible warping and to fit both in the same print;
  • Sliced on Slic3r PE, but the model should work fine with any other;
  • 0,4mm nozzle;
  • 2 perimeters and 3 upper and lower walls, no less;
  • Low infill to spend less material, working fine holding a 1kg spool with this configuration.

description.text:
Hello my fellow Critters,

I designed a thing ;)

It's a Dice Tray with the logo and most used slogan of that show we love.
My Printer is currently Printing one so no foto's yet. You'll have to do with a render for now.

The design is inspired by the thing I "remixed" this from, even though my design is from scratch.
Most notable change, the space to store your dice in is big enough for a d20, the only issue I had with the original.

For postprocessing I recommend you put in some felt or a thin piece of crafting foam, to absorb some of the sound a dice roll makes. But that's personal taste.

Edit: it's just a hair to small ( ~3 or 4mm) to fit a full range of dice ( d20 d12 d10 d8 d6 d4) I'll edit the file tonight and replace the STL with the new one.
Also the outer wall with the text might be to high to be able to get the dice out with ease.
Edit2: The V4 file is 4mm wider and the "rails" keeping the dice in are lower.

I hope you enjoy it!

P.s. The Fusion 360 file is included, so you can modify this thing six ways till Thursday.

description.text:
CUBE LED LAMP

Easy to print
Prints without supports

Cubic LED lamp with minimalistic design. Use transparent filament when used as a LED lamp. Can also be used as a decorative sculpture - use chrome or gold spray paint or granite stone effect spray to achieve a unique look.

The sculpture has a bottom hole (diameter 67.6mm) to hold a LED light gadget. I used the LEDs and battery holders from LED candles, so the lamp can be set to different colors via a small remote control.

You can use an electric turntable to have a rotating LED cube which is solar and / or battery driven (see below). One AA battery lasts for several weeks of continuous movement.

LED candles (use the LED gadget inside): http://ebay.to/2tZLjF1
Electric turntable: http://bit.ly/2sBivCu

Printing:

  • No infill
  • No supports
  • Wall thickness 0.8mm
  • Layer height 0.3mm (or less)
  • Use a raft for best adhesion during printing

Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=s8uAncTCrFA

Securely mount your Arduino and Ramps board with this mounting plate. Tabs have tapered holes to accept #6 wood screws.

Drill the board mounting holes out with a 2.5mm drill and tap with an M3x0.5 tap. I used 1/2" nylon spacers between the Arduino board and the Ramps board. Be careful not to crush the tiny surface mount LED as it is right beside a mounting hole. I used a soldering iron to melt a relief into the spacer. Fasten to your box printer with #6 wood screws.

Hier geht es um meinen Anet A8 auf AM8 Umbau.
Da ich keinen Umbausatz benutzt habe ,habe ich alles selber gezeichnet.
Folgendes wird benötigt.
Die Alu Profile sind 20*40 Nut5 .Die Profile habe in Nut Mitte ein 5er Durchgangsloch.
Hier werden später Gewinde M6 geschnittem.

1)Der Rahmen
2 Profil 500mm Lang(Y) 2 Profil 370mm Lang(Z) 3 Profil 450mm Lang (X)
Zuerst bohren wir in die 3 Z Profile die Löscher
2 der X Profile werden Aufrecht also die 40mm Hochkannt aufgestellt .In der Oberen Nut bohren wir nun 4 6er Löscher Vom Rand 10 und 30 mm (Rechts und Links)
Das 3 X Profil stellen wir auch 40 mm Hochkant bohren aber von oben nach unten auf jeder Seite auch wie oben die Löscher(Gesamt 12 Stk)
Nun nehmen wir die beiden Y Profile (450 mm Lang)Legen sie Flach (40mm Seite unten)auf den Tisch. Beide bekommen von einer Seite aus gerechnet bei 290 mm in jede Nut wie oben ein Loch. Wichtig ist das genaue arbeiten .
In die beiden Y und die beiden Z Profile werden nun die Gewinde geschnitten um sie Später mit den Angebohrten Profilen verschrauben zu können.
Benötigt werden 12 M640 und 4 M660 Schrauben(Diese können wenn das Gewinde tief genug geschnitten wurde auch etwas länger sein.Das Ganze wird nun zu einem Rahmen verschraubt.Da meine Version länger ist als der Originale A8 habe ich mir in der Bucht ein Set mit 2 Linearstangen 4 LagerBöcke und 4 Halterböcke für die Gleitstangen gekauft.
Dieses habe ich mit Nutensteinen verschraubt. Da mit der Alu Bettträger vom A8 nicht gefallen hat,habe ich einen aus Acryl gekauft. Auf diesen ist später auch mein Y Endschalter ausgerichtet.Nun habe ich den Bettträger verschraubt.Da auch der Zahnriemen zu kurz ist habe ich ein 5 M Zahnriemenset gekauft. Den Zahnriemen habe ich mit den Original befestigungen erst mal nur eine Seite befestigt.Nun kommen meine Y Achse Motorhalter und Y Achse Riemenspanner STL zum tragen. Diese werden auch wieder mit Nutensteinen verschraubt(Hier benutze ich M4 16). Der Riemenspanner ist sehr knapp gezeichnet evtl etwas nach feilen. Zum spannen benutze ich eine M560 Schraube .Der Kopf zeigt Richtung Druckbett.Auf die Mutter kommt ein Drehknopf .Damit wäre Y erledigt. Nun kommen meine Z Achse Motorhalter und Halter mit Lager zum tragen. An den Motorhaltern habe ich mit einem 8er Bohrer von hand das Loch entgratet ,so daß die Leitstange eng einpasst. Benötigt werden 20 M316 Schrauben .2 Kugellager 822*8. Alle Halter werden so verschraubt das sie bündig mit den Profilen an den Aussenseiten sind. Da auch die Breite etwas mehr ist wie beim A8 habe ich die beiden Madenschrauben im Rechten weißen Halter gelöst und etwas auseinander gezogen. Nun habe ich zum testen ohne Trapezspindel die X Achse hoch und runter geschoben. Sie muss sehr leichtgängig sein.Dann die Trapezspindeln wie beim Original auch einfügen.
Evtl Das Lager oder beide Spindel an je einer Seite ca 8mm Hoch einen hauch anfeilen.
Vorher Prüfen wie gut das Lager auf die Spindel passt. Muss mit leichtem Druck einzufügen sein. Damit wäre nun auch die Z Achse fertig.
Nun habe ich den Y Endstop montiert. Die Kleinen Schrauben hab ich vom Original benutzt.
Ihn habe ich von hinten gesehen neben dem Lagerbock montiert. So das der Schalter vom Acyrlbettträger bendient wird.Nun kann man das Hotend vom A8 benutzen . Ich habe aber ein E3dV6 Duo montiert. Als X Riemen Spanner beutze ich diesen hier .:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2159366.
Da ich die Anordnung vom Anet A8 betreff Mainboard und Netzteil ganz gut finde, habe ich das übernommen. Hierfür habe ich 2 Grundplatten gezeichnet 1) Für 2 Mosfet 2) Für Arduino mit Ramps. Das Netzteil habe ich Seitlich an den Alu Rahmen geschraubt.
Den Ramps Kühler habe ich auch seitlich von aussen an den Alu Rahmen geschraubt.
So ich habe nun alle STL so wie ich sie an meinem Umbau montiert habe.
Von hinten wird der Bauteilekühlerhalter montiert wo dann die beiden Lüfter rein kommen.
In die Lüfter wird jeweils die Düse gesteckt.
Sollten Fragen oder Verbesserungsvorschlage da sein bitte ich sie gerne zu stellen.
Ps .
Die Arduino Ramps Halterung hat 4 Löscher .Somit ist einer Version mit und ohne Fan Extender
Mit Fan Extender dann die hinteren benutzen

title: 3D Printer Control Box

description.text:
The pictures don't include the door yet, otherwise the they are correct. I still need to do some wiring to finish the control box, but the design works fine.

If you want to see this get developed, and installed, watch my Tevo Black Widow Mods Playlist here: (I will work on this over the next few weeks as well, so subscribe if you want to see them as the videos come out)
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLJKGITN8zPugVZEqNA1bqYd4eg7A3Cfdw

This is a control box design that I made for my Tevo Black Widow 3D printer.

It has built in mounts for Meanwell PSP-600 series PSU's and fits some other models as well. Check their spec sheet to be sure. It doesn' thave any specific mounts for any electronics, but it has 2 panels where you can easily attach some spare aluminium sheets, and mount your electronics on them.

The back panel has 31 holes for aviation connectors. 30 of them are 12mm and 1 is 16mm.
Here you can buy the ones that I used:
12mm: http://bit.ly/2BtC8iD
16mm: http://bit.ly/2Gfl6UL

It also has mounts for a power connector, a backpanel USB B mount and a Molex Mini-fit Jr. 2x4 mount (or a PC 8-pin VGA or CPU power). I use this for powering the heatbed.

On the front side I have mounts for 2x power switches. Please don't ask me to provide any links to the ones I used, as I bought mine from a local store (Bauhaus), and don't have any idea if the ones online are the same size.

The door on the front is magnetic and it is attached by ⌀=5mm h=3mm sized magnets that can be bought here:
http://bit.ly/2syZ8Ko

Soon, I will make a windowed version as well, but until then you can just leave it off if you want to see the inside of the box.

This box uses 3x 120mm fans, 2 as an intake on the left, and 1 as an exhaust on the right size.

Please don't ask me to do any modifications to this box as it took a ton of time to design this, and I don't want to work on this anymore. You are free to remix this design if you need to change something.

Also keep in mind that some of the parts are very large and may not fit a small heatbed. Make sure everything will fit before you try to print this. If you are using a Tevo Black Widow like I do, then this won't be an issue for you.

You will need supports for some of the parts, double check before printing. Also keep in mind the parts are not optimally oriented, so rotate them as necessary before printing.

description.text:
This is an almost completely printable four-threaded fringe twister with a gear ratio of 1:2 (rpm in:out). The largest part fits on a 120x120mm print bed.

I tried printing the clamps at first, but they where too weak, so you can either try to design your own or you can use crocodile clamps (alligator clips?.. Krokodilklemmen in German ;-) .
To attach those, you have multiple options:

  • glue them into the gear_small_w_hole.stl with epoxy or similar gluey stuff
  • heat them up and melt them into the gear_small.stl (high infill) <- my method of choice
  • design your own clamp/adaptor and combine it with small_gear.stl in your favorite cad software. The diameter of the gear shaft is 10.0mm.

I think the rest of the assembly is self explanatory.
Happy twisting

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 to 0.15

Infill:

~25%

Notes:

Avoid blobs at all costs - especially at the gears. So turn on (agressive) coasting, keep it slow and the layer hight low (0.1, 0.15 for the impatient), unless you are 100% confident your printer can handle it.

You obviously need four of either the gear_small.stl or the gear_small_w_hole.stl (see summary above). Even if you only need a two-threaded twister I advise you to use four gears for better stability of the assembly.

I used Autocad Inventor (free for students) to design this thing. If you need to change something, I will provide you with the source files, if you promise not to run off with them, file patent and make big money (unless you share :-P). Just send me a message or leave a comment. If you only need small adjustments like more/less clearance, I can do it for you.

The whole thing is designed to fit a 120x120mm print bed. The base.stl has to be angled diagonally to fit. If you find the base handle to be too small, you can design your own. I included a technical drawing of the base part with hopefully all the needed measurements. Also if you ask nicely, maybe I'll consider designing a bigger one myself ;-)

comments.text: How does it work?
comments.author: PurplePepperEater

comments.text: You clip at least one thread each in two of the crocodile clamps respectively and twist them until they start to curl slightly. When you release them, hold them close together and they start curling around each other.  I think depending on the thread thickness you use one or two threads per clamp and two to four clamps at once.

title: Tak - A Beautiful Game - Garden Version

description.text:
A garden version of "Tak: A Beautiful Game" You can buy the original game on Amazon: https://www.amazon.com/Cheapass-Games-239CAG-Tak-Beautiful/dp/B01LFA7QFK Print 4 of the board pieces, 1 of the middle joiner piece, 1 each of the capstones, and 30 each of the stones/stumps. Painting it is actually quick and easy and looks cool, so don't be afraid of it :-)

I combined/edited/slightly altered 9 different stl files from Thingiverse as well as my own design to create this version. So, a big thank you to: Curufin, dutchmogul, devonjones, Krest, and onebitpixel (you can view their links in the Remix section)

A fair warning, the diamonds are 0.1mm higher than the rest of the playing board. I did this on purpose to make them stand out. If you choose to play on the diamonds, a tall stack of stones can get wobbly if they aren't stacked straight or set down carefully =)

https://youtu.be/Cd97auYCEG0

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

5%

Notes:

3 shells (because of such low infill). The underside of the board pieces have a cut away area to fit into the round middle joiner piece so they at least need a bit of support. Support for the brick corner posts is up to you...

Painting

Besides removing a bit of support material, the only post print processing you'll need to do is painting. If you don't know what dry brushing is, you can research it or view my video https://youtu.be/sJ7gxA4NoyY for an amateur take on it :-)
STONE LOOK:
If you've printed in black filament, the stone look can be achieved quickly by dry brushing on some grey craft paint. If you didn't print in black filament, paint everything black first.
PLANT CAPSTONES:
Paint in green, dry brush on some brown
WOOD PIECES:
Print in white, paint one coat of a lighter brown on either flat side. When that is dry, paint a dark brown on the "bark". Dry brush with a medium or dark green to give it a mossy look.
WATER:
Lightly paint in 3 tones of blue, don't let any of the layers completely dry before adding the next, if you can see brush strokes after the third layer, put a tiny bit of water on a brush and swirl the colors together lightly. When it's how you like it, let it completely dry and brush a good thick layer of clear fingernail polish on top.
GRASS:
Paint with dark green. Dry brush with a little lighter green. Do a third even lighter color green with some dry brush highlights.
DIAMONDS:
One layer of gold or metallic brown paint should do the trick. Add more layers if desired.

description.text:
A simple mount for a J Tech Photonics laser diode (https://jtechphotonics.com) on a generic Prusa i3-style X axis. Designed for a Rework-style X carriage (with four M4 screws), you need to unscrew your hotend/extruder and attach this mount to use the laser. (Any all-in-one solutions I tried limited the workable area of the laser and/or the printer, so until I get around to designing a quick-change X axis, this will have to do!) There's a little gubbin for engaging the X axis endstop, and the positioning of the laser should give it a safe clearance from the bed, but close enough to focus the laser using the Z axis of your printer.

If you need to tweak the dimensions (such as for the X endstop nub), the OpenSCAD file has all of the dimensions broken out as parameters, adjust them as necessary.

title: Monoprice Select Mini extruder cap to replace new OEM design
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Note: I'm pretty happy with my design, and it does work, but it's not a long term solution. For a better solution, check out MPSM V2 Improved Extruder. My piece is something that you could print to get yourself back up and running if the stock top collet breaks, and then use mine to print out that better design.

Older Monoprice Mini printers had a brass locking collet for the PTFE tube at both ends. The newer ones have a very minimal one at the top that locks in place and seems to be cheaply made. Mine broke, so I return/exchanged the printer, and then I saw Bigben2 had the same problem with his and decided to see if I could replace that small, fragile, hard-to-find piece for one of the more standard brass collets.

What I have here is two options to accomplish the same purpose:

  1. Threaded insert
    This piece replaces the original top collect with a printable piece that has an M6 thread so you can thread in the appropriate brass collet. You remove the two screws that hold the black plastic cap on the top of the extruder motor, remove the original collet and replace it with the printed piece threaded onto a brass collet. Because the piece is small, you might need to hold it with pliers as you thread in the brass piece. The threads fit a bit tight.

  2. Replacement top cap
    This piece replaces the original collet as well as the top cap. Currently I have not added threads to this piece, but it is sized to allow an M6 brass collet to be threaded in directly without the need for

Either one of these works, I've printed and tested both.

Some caveats:

  • Thingiverse does strange things with Amazon links, so here's the URL for the brass collets that I purchased: https://amazon.com/gp/product/B019RQ5EYE/ - copy and paste that.
  • Barring the Amazon link, just make sure that you search for "quick connect 4mm PTFE fitting M6" to get the right item. You need something to fit a 4mm PTFE tube and an M6x1 metric thread. There are other threads available, but I sized for the M6.
  • The bowden tube on my printer was a bit too long to begin with, and adding about 18mm with the brass collet makes it even moreso. You may with to shorten your bowden tube after installing this to address the extra length.

If you'd rather just have a spare of the original part, here's a link for a store that carries it: https://gigdigit.com/bowden-coupling-connector-for-the-updated-extruder-feeder-mechanism/

Apologies if the orange hand spinner in the photos offends you... but if you want to print your own, it's right here.

Thanks to McMaster-Carr for the 3D STEP model of the M6 nut that I used for the threads, as I had trouble getting one from Nut Job

Other options

  • MPSM V2 Improved Extruder
    This design replaces the entire extruder base plate, block, and arm with new parts. I had considered something along this line as the next step but honestly this one looks way better than what I would have come up with. The use of the M6 steel nut should also make it more durable in the long term. If your original part broke, you could use my design to print out this one.

Updates:

  • 2018-02-15: I realized I was missing a piece from the extruder top cap which resulted in there being air space which made feeding the filament a little tricky. Removed the original piece and uploaded the modified piece. Have printed the updated piece and am currently using it.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.0875mm

Notes:

I printed these at three shells and 20% infill.

With the smaller part, 3 shells means it's effectively 100% infill anyway.

With the larger part, 20% infill seems sufficient.

No rafts or brims are necessary, I had good results printing with just a skirt to prime the extruder.

I also didn't bother with any supports. The small piece is angled to address overhangs, and the small overhang in the larger part isn't big enough to cause a problem.

title: Anet A8 nozzle clean adapter for Y chain

description.text:
//VERSION 1.1 BE CAREFULL ADD A RYSLAN WITH METAL BRUSH//

Hi,
A way to use the "nozzle clean" of the 1.1.8 Marlin firmware on the anet A8. Fits perfectly on the Y chain mod.
Print at 0,2.
Use cyano to glue a brush (metal brush or mat, whatever not quickly inflammable)

//Salut,
une facon simple d'utiliser la fonction "nozzle clean" de marlin 1.1.8 sur l'ANET A8.s'adpate parfaitement sur la modification de chaine de cable de l'axe Y.
Imprimez à 0,2.
Utilisez de la cyano pour coller la brosse (métallique ou bout de paillasson, ou tout ce qui n'est pas inflammable rapidement....)//

Modify marlin : modifiez Marlin :

define NOZZLE_CLEAN_FEATURE

if ENABLED(NOZZLE_CLEAN_FEATURE)

// Default number of pattern repetitions

define NOZZLE_CLEAN_STROKES 12

// Default number of triangles

define NOZZLE_CLEAN_TRIANGLES 3

// Specify positions as { X, Y, Z }

define NOZZLE_CLEAN_START_POINT { -10, 110, (Z_MIN_POS + 10)}

Here's my approach to improving the X5S heat bed performance.

  1. Insulate Heat Bed
  2. Add Power MOFEST Bed Control.
  3. Increase Bed Power from 12 Vdc to 21 Vdc
  4. OPTIONAL
    Add 24 VDC LED light strips for Stage Lighting
    Add Digital Volts/Amps meter to monitor Bed Operation

Details of above are found in the attached PDF file.

MARCH 1, 2018 UPDATE: I have located and purchased a number of 8.5 VDC 40 AMP power supplies that work great for this project. Check out this eBay listing (Item ID: 142707783864). if your are interested

MARCH 3, 2018 UPDATE: I have updated the PDF file to better explain the schematic and power supply approach. I hope this answers a few questions I've received.

CAUTIONS:
Use heavy gauge wiring throughout bed circuits. To avoid hot spots, failures and fires, be sure all wire terminals are properly attached, all screw terminals are tightened, and all wire junctions are solid.

comments.text:

author: Werner

title: CR-10 Double X stepper damper bracket

description.text:
Stepper dampers make a huge difference in the sound levels of 3D printers. A small disadvantage is that the flexible dampers can bend resulting a a belt not running straight of the gear.

A solution is to mount a 2nd damper on the back of the NEMA17 stepper. For the Y axis there are already a few designs on thingiverse. I recommend Scolle_'s design. The bending problem is smaller on the X axis, but i wanted to fix this anyway.

This design can easily be added to any CR-10 without removing to much parts. It does however require turning the stepper 90deg. so the connector on the stepper can be reached. I'm considering editing the model to remove this is enough people request this.

I'm also considering other mods like a filament guidance. To me however this design is just a proof of concept as i will be making a new one supporting a drag chain and connection box for the hotend wires. At this poin i'm not sure when such a design will be finished.

IMPORTANT: I'm sure not a stepper dampers are created equal. The thickness of the damper is important to the design. I used dampers i bought on aliexpress. Seller name is Funssor. These are approx 6mm thick excluding the center ring.

comments.text:
Hi,
Thanks a lot for this design ! it works incredibly well !!! very very silent and rigid on the CR-10S !!! there is just an interference with the filament detector plate but nothing important.
I'm looking for the Y one but i don't find it over here? do you have any link ?
Regards.
Manu

print_settings.Notes:: Key parts

description.text:
These are magnetically actuated drawer locks.

Items needed:

  • 8mmx3mm magnet gets pressed into slot in 'Lever'

  • 3/16"x1/16" magnet gets pressed into slot on bottom of 'Housing'. Make sure you orient this so it pushes the lever up. There's a hole on the opposite side to push the magnet out if needed.

  • 3/4"x3/8" magnet used to unlock -- just put in front of the lock on the outside of drawer (seen in 4th picture)

  • 1.58"x1.58" 3M mounting pads to stick the housing to the inside of drawer -- cut a hole or leave backing on area where the 'Lever' contacts the adhesive.

  • A #14x3/4" nail (or longer) to push through the housing and lever. It press fits in the housing and the lever rotates freely on it. I only had 1.25" length on hand so I just cut to size.

To stick the 'Catch' cut a piece of adhesive pad to size.

The catch mounts on the bottom of the drawer hole in the cabinet. Line it up in the center, stick it, then mount the lever/housing assembly high enough so the lever will snag on the catch.

Three perimeters for strength, supports where necessary. If you print these in a different orientation they may undesirably shear, however, in their current orientation my almost-two-year-old hasn't been able to break them.

Key parts
0.15mm layer height for "top" & "bottom" parts, washer is fine with 0.2mm layer height.
I basically copied ''Enovoe Magnetic Safety Locks' that I purchased on Amazon. They worked great and we needed more so why not see if I can print them?

description.text: This is a nameplate I made for a friend

One of my coworkers brought in a few lengths of bright yellow plastic chain that he wanted to use to cordon off a section of shelves with. At first, he wanted to cut out a little piece of one link and then glue it into the gap at an angle to make a hook out of it. I offered to print something a little bit slicker in appearance, and this is the result.

The smaller, or economy, version is the first one made before widening the hook and giving it a second screw hole for stability.

The halves are held together with #4-40 screws but M3 will work as well. A wood screw could also work if you didn't need to disassemble it later.

title: PigEarth Ganger (Teledrome model)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
We Kickstarted our latest 3d-print-and-play board game, Teledrome at the tail end of 2017, and it's now available on our online storefront!

In Teledrome, you take the role of a ruthless fight promoter, assembling and training a diverse force of gladiators to battle in televised events broadcast across the Wayfarer Multiverse.

This is one of 20 characters included with the base game (all of which will print without support). We've got a few expansions slated for release soon, including more characters, a full arena terrain set and a 28mm-optimized version of the game. description.text:
Finally got those extra mirror tiles I bought for my CR-10 off my desk and stored properly!

Thanks to arod24 and his original Glass Bed Shelf, this is slight remix that removes a lot of material so that it prints faster.

Supports 5 pieces of glass with maximum thickness of 4mm. Space them however far apart you need for your glass width.

Would also work well to store sheets of glass on their side, just mount the brackets on the side of a cabinet vertically.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

15+%

Notes:

Originally, I tried printing this with only 5% infill in hopes of reducing the print time even further, but the print failed because I was trying to print in wood (it's a shelf, so I figured wood) but just didn't have it dialed in properly and with so much space in the infill, it wasn't able to properly put a top-layer on the infill pattern.

I switched to PLA and upped the infill to 15% and it prints beautifully.

Takes around 16 hours though, printing at 50mm/s. Still a lot better than the 26hr+ estimate for the original that scared me into making this remix.

https://youtu.be/r7RzW7fvfyc

Remove the shelf if possible so you don't have to work upside down. Position the brackets exactly where you want with a piece of glass held in the brackets so you can make sure it's will be just how you want it later. Remove the glass, mark the location of the holes and pre-drill for screws.

I used short brass wood screws that were shorter than the depth of my shelf. The holes have an inset for the screw head so everything can mount flush and not interfere with the top slot.

print_settings.Notes:: elephant's foot

description.text:
This is a demonstrator of a rack-and-pinion gear mechanism. The 20 pinion gear teeth have an involute profile, while the 15 rack teeth have a flat trapezoidal profile. Both have a module of 2mm.

This builds on an earlier gear demonstrator of mine which investigated the involute tooth profile.

The holes in the base a meant to accomodate a #8 screw for mounting.

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

%20

Notes:

Print with a low bed heat (or none) to avoid any elephant's foot, which will cause mechanical interference between the gear teeth and make additional post processing necessary.

This model is designed to be assembled using three M3x5mm Threaded Inserts, inserted into the slightly undersized holes using a soldering iron. (Matterhackers has a good guide to this method). The pinion is held by a small (~8mm x m3) machine screw. The rack is guided by two screws of the same type.

The Involute profile was hand-modelled in Fusion 360 using an approximation method. The rack dimensions were calculated using the equations in Part 3 of This Page. and verified with the Rack and Pinion Calculator from Otvinta.

title: TronXY X5S Bed Sensor Extender v2

description.text:
This Z endstop switch mount for the TronXY X5S moves the standard endstop switch to the actual print bed, instead of relying on the proxy of the original adjustable M3 screw. With this arrangement, the bed can be swapped without the need for re-calibrating because the switch always is triggered by the top of the bed and not some fixed position of the undercarriage.

Additional items required: A M4 screw and a T-nut for attaching it to the frame, and a wooden screw 3 mm x 16 mm (depends on you setup).

Do check that no collision occurs between the rear part and the moving platform and the rollers. It is supposed to be mounted just outside the frame, with only the switch protruding into the print bed.

description.text:
I've included a couple of screenshots from Slic3r, in an attempt to demonstrate the most complicated feature to print in this model. The cut-away screenshot, shows three parallel lines, designed to be bridged. It may be necessary to run a bridging test,to ensure you can print this part successfully.

The model shown in the photos is the first one made and tested by the individual who requested I print this. It's worked for a few nights, without a compression failure, and is reportedly comfortable. It's held on with a 2cm wide Neoprene strap, designed for sunglasses.

It was printed in ASA, with 3 perimeters, and 20% infill.

After printing, due to steep overhangs, some surface sanding is required, and the bridges need to be cut, to allow the strap to be fitted. I sanded this one quite thoroughly as it's a wearable.

Das Filament https://www.thingiverse.com/dasfilament_de made a great remix of the
Original Masterspool by RichRap: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2769823

I wanted to use it with the spool holder: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1832235

So I remixed it by reducing the arm lengths slightly and adding the outer guide so that it works with the roller type spool holders.

It's weighs around 60g and has a diameter of 200mm.
The 206mm version weighs roughly 8g more.

[Update 08-03-2018]
Added a 206mm version to try make it compatible with more rolling spool holders.
Also fixed a small error in the outer guide mesh, but had little or no impact when sliced.
I will not be making any further updates to this version.
I tried it with the Das Filament refill and it was ok.
(I'm currently developing a Roller v2 that I will release soon)

It doesn't work with all rolling type spool holders, but I tried to keep as close as possible to the original size and I am yet to test whether the reduced arm length still works well with a refill.

title: DPS-600PB Power Supply Mount for Anet A8

description.text: I created this so I could mount an HP DPS-600PB power supply on my Anet A8 as a replacement for the stock power supply.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

The resulting print will fit rather loosely around the supply - this is on purpose. I used some pieces of thin (1.5mm) craft foam (neoprene?) wedged between the power supply and the mount to avoid vibrations.

The top mount is installed upside down from the way it prints - i.e. the mounting "ears" are on the bottom.

I have two short (~10cm) pairs of 14AWG silicone wires soldered directly to the output blades of the power supply - spread the blade, insert the wire strands between the blades, add plenty of solder, heat shrink over the whole thing. Then each pair goes to an Anderson PowerPole connector pair. I use one pair to power the printer motherboard and the other pair goes to the external MOSFETs for the bed and hot end. XT60 connectors would work just as well as the PowerPoles, and you could just run a single 12AWG wire across to the electronics if you like.

description.text: I needed some quick and cheap fluid filters for a prototype piece of field research equipment.  Here's a quick way to make coarse and relatively fine fluid filters of almost any diameter and contour shape (round, square, irregular etc...) using a simple trick where you create a solid object like a shallow cylinder then STOP the print just after the raft is set down and BEFORE the object starts printing. You are using the RAFT as the fluid filter not the object that defines the contour. You have a useable fluid filter in less than 3 minutes that has a "pore" size down to about 50-100 microns (yes I checked on an optical micrometer). The pore size can be 1mm if you only let the first layer of the raft print.  It goes down to 50-100 microns if you let the overlying raft layers print also.  You can also eliminate the outer rim if you want by changing the settings for the print.  One nice feature is the automatic support bars that are laid down under the raft.  I printed this on an UP!3D printer at normal resolution.

Print out any solid shape, but STOP the print after one or more of the support raft layers prints then use the raft as a quick customizable fluid filter. As you can see the object is just a shallow cylinder. It has a diameter of 30mm and the raft is set at 5mm so the filter will have a diameter of 40mm with a 5mm rim. You can trim the rim or create any kind of filter holder that you need. Inspired by (but with different approach) user: Wauter Fine Mesh Screen http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27805

I'm happy with the results so far, but there's always room for improvement. The stand is sturdy though it would benefit from a thin foam or rubber footing.

title: Mean Well LRS-50-5 box and lid with 45° ventilation holes
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A little box for my power supply (Mean Well LRS-50-5) that i use for led's and other things that requires 5V.

I added two types of lid one with went holes and one without.

The lid that uses holes it seams like Simplify 3D is not able to open it so you have to slice it in Ultimaker Cura.

I designed the holes so they lean 45 degrees so the ventilation goes upwards (hot air will travel upwards), and the mounting holes goes down.

I had trouble to print the 1.0 mm holes so i did one with 1.4 mm which is the one i have taken pictures on, the other left holes but it felt it would not serve to good ventilation for the power supply.

2018-02-24:
Added a cover that could be fit over the cables outlets so it look a bit nicer.
MeanWell-LRS-50-5-cover-small.stl (Glue this on the cover, used for cover my led pipe)

128 x 86,6 x 36.5 mm (without lid)
128 x 86,6 x 38.5 mm (with lid)

Inner dimensions, power supply placement:
105 x 82,6 x 32.4 mm
Walls are 2 mm thick, i printed with small infill but i think its better to use 100% infill if the screws should be able to be tighten.

My print was done with:
Creality CR-10S

description.text:
These skis are designed for a Traxxas Rustler but could probably be adapted for other rear-wheel-drive / 2-wheel-drive R/C cars. The spring keeps the front tip up when/if the weight comes off. There stanchion part prints with a hole through it length-wise for inserting one end of the spring. The grooves on the bottom of the ski should give a little more grab for steering.

(Planning to add more photos soon.)

To print:

  • (4) bushings
  • (1) left stanchion
  • (1) right stanchion
  • (2) skis

Note: The skis may print more cleanly if they're printed "on edge". The support material ends up around the pivot-risers instead of under the curved tips.

Note: Since the camber and tow on the left and right are opposite, but the spring is not mirrored, the left and right stanchions are two different parts.

Note: The spring hole comes very close to the edge of the "leg" on the stanchion so, depending on printer resolution, it may show through or even leave an opening.

Note: For strength, at least the stanchion should be printed solid (100% infill). It may be ok to print the ski part at less than 100% infill, but that would affect how much it would tolerate abrasion (from patches of dry pavement, rocks, or dirt).

The pivot bolt is a M4-0.7 x 35 mm "cap screw" and matching nylon lock nut.

  • Home Depot SKU: 577742 and 594265
    The spring comes out of a Harbor Freight "1-1/2 in. Nylon Spring Clamp".
  • Harbor Freight Item#: 69292

Assembly:
1) Insert a spring in the bottom part of each stanchion with the exposed "leg" of the spring pointing towards the rear (vehicle-wise).
2) Position the rocker part of each stanchion between the risers on one of the skis so the longer end of the ski points toward the rear (vehicle-wise).
3) Slide a bolt through a bushing, and then through one ski-riser, through the rocker part of the stanchion, and through the other riser.
4) Slide another bushing on the "nut end" of the bolt before adding the nut. Note: The bushings should slide all the way into the ski-risers on both sides.
5) Install the ski-stanchion assemblies on the car, in place of the front wheels, so that the tabs line up on either side of the steering arm, preventing the stanchion from rotating.

author: asaphx

title: Flip Lid Magic Deck Box with Latch

description.text:
Wanted a simple, small, and durable printed version, most the deck boxes on thingiverse are over-elaborate for my tastes. Only part needed that isn't printed is a single paper clip for the hinge. Files are uploaded in the orientation i printed them (only one with brim/support is the lid). Feel free to engrave designs onto the back or modify the case, for example see picture 2 witch has my logo. Commander size currently untested.

Assembly: Print each file (box, lid, latch, cover, and 2x spring) Place springs inside grooves on lid. Place latch between the springs. Place cover atop the springs, when satisfied you may glue this cover on the 3 raised portions for a more permanent fit. Place lid assembly on box. Straighten a single standard paperclip and thread it through the holes on the back of the box and lid. I usually leave the extra paper clip on the box, and just pinch the extra to the sides of the box.

To be Addressed: Deck box opening if turned upside down and shook (version of lid with 2 latches?)

Made with Sketchup, fits 60 or 100 sleeved cards.

Latch mechanism based off micro lock by caganseval.

Design process

Inspiration from ultraPro deck boxes like this one: https://www.amazon.com/Artist-PRO-Tower-Deck-Box/dp/B01J897R1S/ref=pd_sim_21_4?_encoding=UTF8&pd_rd_i=B01J897R1S&pd_rd_r=H9HE7BVFDSRSEF6YJJ6T&pd_rd_w=GwSkh&pd_rd_wg=3VCP7&psc=1&refRID=H9HE7BVFDSRSEF6YJJ6T&dpID=41hoD1lq23L&preST=_SY300_QL70_&dpSrc=detail

I started by designing a box that held 2 decks face to face, but soon changed to a single deck with a unique triangular cutout to see the front card art.
How i got to here:
v0.1: printed successfully but required sanding a lot of post print work. On top of that to achieve the "flip" case i wanted i was using a card-stock hinge so it wouldn't stand the test of time.
v0.2: I went for more of the ultra pro design adding an area fro dice behind the cards, an idea for a latch system and beefing up the hinge design by using m4 screws. I didn't spend enough time before printing this design and it was non functional and still required a lot of internal cleaning.
v0.3: Combining ideas from v2 with v1, i successfully printed what i was looking for. Using the 3d printed spring from caganseval's model, lid from v2, and case from v1, i was satisfied and went on to tune it further
v0.4: Made walls a little thicker and beveled them to smooth out prints, experimented with orientation and fine tuning tolerances.
v0.5: First Public release.

title: Space Alert Reactor Fuel Rod Holder

description.text:
A small printed accessory for Vlaada Chvátil's excellent fast-paced board game "Space Alert."

At the start of each mission, your ship has three fuel rods to spend for additional power cubes. Left to their own devices these fuel rods have a habit of rolling away, so I quickly designed this small spaceship "reactor" print to keep them in one spot.

There's a space underneath to glue or otherwise attach a US 5c coin or similar to add just a bit of extra weight to the piece.

The original version kept just a little too tight of a grip on the fuel rods as it printed on my cheap machine, so the uploaded model has the holes slightly enlarged. FreeCAD file included in case they need further tweaking on your printer. If your fuel rods are like mine, they're just barely wider at one end than the other, so keep that in mind. You don't want to be fumbling to remove the rods while the timer counts down!

author: asaphx

description.text:
I find these coin-pendants a pleasing way to display the plane curves from thing:26973, Decorative Disks. The coins have milled edges and curves on each face. They can be used as key fobs or pendants and are about the size of checker pieces. The coins can be printed without holes or with two different types of holes. A hole through the face of the coin makes it suitable for use as a key fob. A hole through the edge allows a ribbon to be threaded through making the coin a pendant. See the image at the upper left. Three pairs of stl files for two color printers are provided.
They are: 1) a key fob with devil and witch of agnesi curves -
coin_less_devil_witch.stl and devil_witch.stl 2) a pendant with 7 cusped hypocycloid and epicycloids -
coin_less_hypo_epicycloid.stl and hypo_epicycloid.stl 3) a simple disk with no holes -
coin_less_devil_form_evolute.stl and devil_form_evolute.stl The openSCAD program that produces the coins is included below. There are hundreds of types of coins possible as most of the plane curve modules have adjustable parameters.

The coins are 35 mm in diameter and 5 mm thick.  A 2 mm thick decoration occurs on the front and back face.  Eight additional plane curve modules have been added to those from thing:26973 so that there are a total of 20 modules available.
The openSCAD program is similar to the one used for thing:26973.  One chooses which type of hole to have by uncommenting the code producing the type of hole required or leaves all the hole commands commented out to produced a coin without holes.  One decoration is chosen from each of two lists and the other members are commented out.  The program is run once using the difference statement to make a file like coin_less_devil_witch.stl and a second time with the intersection command to make devil_witch.stl.
They look best printed with either no shells or one shell and are sturdiest with a fair amount of infill.

Needed a small vacuum to clean up my work area after all the messes that accrue. Rather than spend $30 on a small shop vac, I figured it could be an interesting opportunity to see how sturdy of a print I could make while testing out how accurate I could print threads generated in Fusion 360. I went to a local goodwill and bought a corded dust buster for $3, a seal-able ammo can from harbor freight, and a couple other components. In all it cost around $10. I used extra filament which is why the assembly is three colors. overall it works a hell of a lot better than the original used vacuum, but I would've maybe chosen a more powerful impeller motor if I were starting over.

title: Custom SuperMagnum Fan Bracket
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
WARNING: This version DOES NOT WORK. This version is too tall, and too wide and contacts the front X-Axis drive belt.

This is a better centrifugal blower/fan bracket for the "SuperMagnum" circular fan duct by Reflector, found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2452863

This is only the fan bracket. I have not made any changes to Reflector's excellent duct design.

Fits the same 40x40x20mm centrifugal fan as mentioned in the original part, but has better attachment points in the right positions, and a bit of a lip or ledge for the fan to sit on, so it's not prone to sliding through the hole. Requires 3 M3x20mm machine screws and nuts. Hex socket head or pan head can be used. (Longer ones can be used if the head is placed on the fan side facing the rear of the printer and the nut against the bracket / towards the front of the printer, but it would be safer to trim them off with a rotary tool cut-off wheel. Pan head screws would provide more clearance than hex socket head screws if installed in this orientation.)

If you really want a great seal, spread a thin layer of RTV sealant, hot glue, silicone caulk, etc, around the edge of the fan, and on the mating surfaces of the bracket and duct. (This is totally unnecessary, and a bit messy... At least in my clumsy hands. ;-P )

Fan Installation Note: You will need to flex the bracket "towers" slightly to get the fan in. Shouldn't take much pressure, though.

title: Bee Feeder and Waterer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hello! I designed this bee feeder (not to be confused with the stoic Beefeaters of old). The idea is simple - provide a nice place where bees can collect water for their pollenation, feeding, and hive-keeping chores.

The feeder requires a "wide mouth" mason jar as water container. I used a Ball wide mouth jar with an outside diameter of 3 3/8" (86mm).

In my yard I keep blue orchard bees (BOBs) and green orchard bees (GOBs), both of which need ready sources of water and dirt to make mud walls protecting their eggs.

Their little homes and this freshwater bath are the least I can offer these fellas helpfully pollinating my garden!

This is a single piece print that needs no supports or rafts. Enjoy!

title: Driver holder - 15 pc - wall mount - 23mm size

description.text:
Wall mount 15 pc high density hand driver holder, 23mm hole side, handle side down, nut side up for easy identification and fit test without need to remove the tools, tools stays upright and tidy.

Scale X and Y to adjust to your hole size needs.

Scale Z to your height need of bottom piece and don't have to use the top piece, but this could use more material vs using shorter top and bottom pieces.

Originally made for Harbor Freights nut drivers, but I had to scale X and Y to 1.05 to make it fit all the drivers as they do vary within the same set.

Bottom piece has a beveled base to keep the tool from falling through. Top piece has consistent hole dimension all the way though.

To print a quick test fit for your drivers, print the first couple of layers of the top piece as a template, remove it from the bed and test if all your drivers fit to your liking, scale X and Y as required.

description.text:
Makruk

Makruk is a chess-like game from Thailand. The objective, as in chess, is to put the opponent's king into checkmate, however, the move sets of the pieces and starting formation are different. Included in this thing entry are STL files and FreeCAD project files in case you wish to modify or remix this set.

Pieces & Movesets:

  • Pawn (Cowry Shell) : starts on 3rd rank and moves like a chess pawn until it reaches the 6th rank at which point it is promoted to a makruk "queen" by flipping the piece over. It then has the same moveset as the "queen" described below. These pieces are also good for checkers sets since they can be promoted by flipping, no stacking/spare pieces needed.

  • Knight (Horse): same move set and starting position as in chess.

  • Rook (Boat): same move set and starting position as in chess.

  • Bishop (Nobleman): can move 1 position along any diagonal as well as 1 position forward. The bishop has the same starting position as in chess.

  • Queen (Seed): can move 1 position along any diagonal. Yes, compared to chess the queen is very nerfed. The queen always starts the game to the right of the king. This is different from chess where the queen sits on her color.

  • King (Feudal Lord): same move set as in chess.

More information can be found here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Makruk

title: RunCam Split 2 - Martian II Top Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The RunCam Split 2 sounds like an amazing piece of kit on paper.....

  • FPV and HD Camera all in one
  • Wide dynamic range camera
  • Records at 1080 60fps
  • Lightwieght
  • No need for a GoPro

What's not to like??

Latency, That's what.

The latency was bad enough for me that I was unable to fly comfortably with it. I know that there's people out there who say that the latency doesn't bother them, but they're not me.

But aside form the latency it's still a pretty good HD camera so I figured why not use it as one. I found Daubut's top mount design for the Split and decided to try it out. I think it's a great design, but there were a couple of things that I wanted to see so I decided to make my own version of the model.

This design fits on top of the Martian II frame, has a 45° incline and the lens of the RunCam is recessed to provide a bit more protection. It also features a hollow bottom that allows for easier placement of the camera.

This model is designed to be printed in TPU or similar semi-flexible filament so the fit is very tight. I don't know weather or not using ABS, PETG, PLA or any other type of filament will work with this model. Conciser yourselves warned.

I printed mine with 100% infill and 0.20mm layer height.

description.text: This is a cup to go with the stamp I made earlier. The idea is to be able to pour the wax without making a mess, which I found is very hard. Even a small flame will melt a good amount of wax quickly. As you can see in the pictures above, the result is a very clean little puddle of wax.

Printer:

Kossel Delta

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

fine

Infill:

20%

Notes:

If you are going to use this cup the way I did (as a candle holder that makes it easy to pour) I recommend using a material with a higher melting point, IE ABS rather than PLA and ceramic over ABS.

Make some insulation

Since I used PLA I wanted at least some barrier between the hot wax and the plastic. What I decided on was to coat the inside of the cup with epoxy resin, then stick sheets of aluminum foil to it. This had the double effect of making the cup less likely to melt and helping it hold shape if it did.

Make the candle

To make the wick, I took a strip of tissue paper and rolled it into a tight cylinder. (A normal candle wick works if you have one) Then I melted wax until it was very fluid an poured it into the cup with the wick sticking straight up. After it set I had a candle!

Note: I used white candle wax and colored it with crayon.

description.text:
This is a redesign of an 18th century artifact from the Northwest Coast of North America, by the Nuxalk tribe of Native Americans. It represents the sun, surrounded by the four supernatural carpenters who created the world according to the myth. In the theater, it was hoisted and lowered to represent the passage of time.

The original was carved from wood and painted.
I designed this version as 100 pieces that snap together. When completed, it measures 33.5cm in diameter, or about 13 inches.

Special shout out to the Natives of the Northwest Coast. Let's keep the past alive thru art!

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

You will need at least a 20x20cm bed to print this.

I labeled the files according to color, then number. You can either buy 4 different colors of filament, or print them all the same and spraypaint them in groups to get exactly the colors you want.

DO NOT USE SUPPORT MATERIAL, except on one piece. That piece is the set of large red lips.

The reason I made the small eyes and teeth separate pieces is so you have the option to print or spray the faces a different color, and still keep those pearlies glistening.

The parts are designed to fit together and hang on the wall, with no need for mechanical fasteners. However, I recommend some type of glue to hold on the blue pieces of the large face, and large eyebrows.

1) Assemble the four red quadrants with the long blue pieces to form the outer ring.
2) Snap on the long white clips to hold the ring together.
3) Snap on the small white faces. Turn the entire ring upside down and pinch together the red prongs sticking out of the hands. Push these prongs into the backs of the white faces.
4) Slide the big red nose through the back of the big white face. Push until it clicks in.
5) Snap the black ring down over the large white head.
6) Flip the head and the ring assembly over, and squeeze the red links into the back of the white head.
7) At twelve spots on the red links, snap in the small white staples until they click into the white head.

Now you've got all the important pieces in place, the structure should hold together you can complete the rest of the mask in any order.

comments.text: Amazing job making this out of individual pieces for an easy color print option.  Beautiful mask.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: My roommate shattered my charging base cup so I fixed it.

Printer:

Monoprice Mini V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.175 (Normal)

Infill:

20%

Notes:
Stand Sizes

I only printed the largest stand so I can't attest to how the small stand will work. The other two were quick redesigns when I realized that the large one takes forever to print, and that it also uses 28 grams of filament.

I can confirm that the large and medium size stands will fit snugly and charge because the medium's contacting edges are the same, only the external faces were shrunk down. The smallest relies on my model of the charger's inner face being correct, which I doubt it is. However, it does have a small upper lip so it should work fine, just be warned.

Printing Suggestions

Use Cura so you can use the ironing feature to ensure that the plate is sealed against water.

Lay the models down normally, the same orientation they would be if you put them on your charger. I'm too lazy to figure out how to orient the STL exports properly, so you need to rotate the model to lay flat on the bed. S3D's lay flat function kinda leaves room for error.

Use a skirt, not raft or brims. I used brims but that made getting it off a pain because of the massive surface area. YMMV.

Printing Times

S3D puts the large stand at 2 hours, Cura said 4. I used Cura. Given, my S3D settings aren't dialed in very much and my Cura settings are set for detail.

Note: I didn't have an original stand to model off of so it's a bit inaccurate, my stand kinda wobbles a bit but I think sanding an edge will fix it.

I modeled the charger and made a negative. But modeling curves is hard so it's still off, but not as much. If anyone has suggestions on how to model curves accurately, let me know! Thanks!

title: Precious Plastic Small-scale extrusion screw for plastics recycling

description.text:
Precious Plastic is an awesome open source effort to make small plastic-recycling machines readily available to folks around the world. If you don't know about it, check out PreciousPlastic.com for more info.

This extrusion screw is a special type of screw designed specifically for extruding plastic, the expanding inner thread puts pressure on the plastic as it melts, providing pressure for higher detail.

Normally extrusions screws are strictly industrial- extremely large, hard to source, and extremely expensive. PP designed this version designed specifically for home-scale extrusion, but they only shared the file as an STP and IGS file, not an STL. So I just converted it to STL, and posted it here. Use at your own risk.

In order to work, this part needs to be metal, not plastic. I'm sharing it here because I suspect that this part could be printed in PLA and then lost-PLA cast in Aluminum. If so, this will make a very difficult to source part much more accessible.

It could also be CNC milled on a lathe. Go nuts! If you learn something, be sure to share!

description.text:
Heart shape via the function:

f(t) = 
    [18  * pow(sin(t),3),
    15  * cos(t) - 5 * cos(2*t) - 2 * cos(3*t) - cos(4*t)
 ];

You can experiment with function parameters and generate OpenSCAD code on the interactive page

http://kitwallace.co.uk/3d/knot-braid.xq?preset=9

Two joined hearts use a hulled-sphere construction because the standard polyhedral construction doesn't play well with CSG operations in OpenSCAD

Printer:

Prusa I3

2d hearts easy but Slic3r doesn't like them, ok with Cura.

title: Thai Reach E-Nable Phoenix Hand Pen Holder mod - Wichit Edition

description.text:
This is a simple pen holder mod designed to be attached by screw or ca glue next to the thumb in an E-nable Phoenix hand or Unlimbited Arm. It is angled and positioned so the thumb and index finger support it like a hand would (see photos for placement). It's based on the Book Cover Pen Holder by AtomKemp.

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:171002

We made this as a request from Mr. Wichit a man in Thailand who lost his arm below the elbow and for many years would strap a pen to his stump to write. Now as part of the Thai Reach Sirindhorn Hospital Sai Jai Thai project to help Veterans with limb disabilities we are making him an Unlimbited Arm with the mod attached.

This very much a work in progress and we are planing to improve this so it has more functionality and more adjustable. This Wichit edition fits most pen sizes and works better on adult sized hands.

author: timbologist

description.text:
Disclaimer I want to make it clear that I do not make any claims at this being the best way to remove a tick or the safest. I also do not make any claims that this has a 100% success rate at removing ticks. Please use at your own discretion and after doing your own research. Consider contacting a medical professional who is more suitable for these tasks if you do not feel comfortable doing this yourself. I made this for my own personal use and am sharing it with anyone else who is interested in using it or improving on the design. Disclaimer

Best design is version 2 and is best printed upside down on most printers. I have added my first design which includes an unintentional hole just for anyone who is curious about my progress or may prefer this design.

Ticks are dangerous and nasty little creatures and they hurt the ones we love, sometimes even ourselves. Only thing more dangerous about them than what they actually do is also in how you remove them. If you remove them improperly, you can create additional problems such as infection due to not completely removing the tick and possibly leaving the head behind.

With a design such as this, it is my hope that you do not have to directly come into contact with the tick and you can remove them in addition to disposing of them as safely as possible.

This design is most like a modified spoon that has a triangular shape to it to aid in removing the tick easily and safely.

To use this, put the spoon down on the skin and move towards the tick with the tick in the path of the open triangle. Once the tick is in between the triangle, pull upwards and in the same direction you were traveling and the tick should come right off the skin. Blood may appear once the tick is removed which is natural. Tend to the area appropriately to cease the blood flow; possibly consider using some type of cleaner such as hydrogen peroxide around the area to help in reducing any chances of infection.

The bowl design is to ensure that the tick is held so that it cannot fall and be lost or force you to come into contact with the tick. I usually flush the tick down the toilet but you can also throw them into a fireplace or dispose of them by other means, perhaps release them elsewhere if you do not want to kill them.

The pictures above show a hole in the bowl. That hole is not intentional but occurred during my first print after designing. The problem was that my design was sitting beneath the "floor" and that part was unintentionally cut off. I didn't realize until the printing had finished. The new design, which is the second and most current, fills this hole. I have added my first design in this anyway for anyone who may want it or to see my progress.

Additionally, the first version is bigger, 25% to be exact. I do not feel that it is necessary to be this large and have reduced the size by 25% in the second version. Scale up or down depending on how you feel you will use this.

I have used a tool that resembles this with ticks on my dog and also fleas and have had great success. My intention with this design was to recreate that object as close as I could as I lost it.

I hope this helps you as it has helped me.

Update: It might be my printer that is causing the hole in the top part of the bowl. I attempted to print the updated version recently and found that it too had a hole in the top of it. Let me know if this happens to you as well so I can look into it. I use a Monoprice Select Mini V2 for my prints.

Additionally, I suppose my measurements were way off or Cura is acting strange with me. When I went in to set it up for the print, it was vastly bigger than expected. I scaled it down to 25% and it is at the size I intended. Please let me know if this happens to you so I can fix it as well.

I'm very new to the design process, so please be patient with me!

This is a Bitcoin Cookie Cutter. It is for shaping cookie dough (or any other substance for that matter - be creative) into a Bitcoin Symbol.

I recommend using PLA for any food touching object or children's toy, since most of the other materials are poisonous or at least not completely safe.

Print it with the top faced to the building plate.

If u have recommendations of any kind to make this a better design please don't hesitate to contact me.

Step 1

Let the cookie cutter cool down before you peel it from your printing bed.

Step 2

Look for little material artifacts and cut them off carefully

Step 3

Wash the cookie cutter carefully under warm (not hot) water

Step 4

Cut your cookie dough

Step 5

Wash the cookie cutter under warm water (It might deform in the dishwasher since PLA gets soft at around 65 °C)

Step 6

Enjoy your cookies :-)
It s branded with the name of my channel. If you want it removed or changed to a different slogan or name so you could use it as a gift for example, feel free to message me

Bitcoin is a cryptocurrency and worldwide payment system. It is the first decentralized digital currency, as the system works without a central bank or single administrator. The network is peer-to-peer and transactions take place between users directly, without an intermediary. These transactions are verified by network nodes through the use of cryptography and recorded in a public distributed ledger called a blockchain. Bitcoin was invented by an unknown person or group of people under the name Satoshi Nakamoto and released as open-source software in 2009.

title: Practical super-capacitor array enclosure (1x6, 16.2v)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a simple, and hastily drawn, enclosure for one of my many super-capacitor arrays, specifically six 500F in series WITH management board, totaling ~83F. The pictured unit will be going on the 12 volt side of my printer to alleviate print failures caused by brownouts. Please note, I am not driving a heated bed with this. Since my printer uses a 10kg+ aluminum plate for a bed, I am using 800w of heating elements on AC via MOSFET control. While a supercap array can drive those heaters, it would not last very long before the printer crashes. Supporting the hotend and steppers would be suitable. I will be limiting my output current to around 4.8 amperes, with a 7.5 ampere blade fuse, utilizing SWG 16 stranded wire. Without current limitation, you'd basically be exposing your power supply to a dead short, practically speaking, until the unit starts gaining stored current. Without fusing, you risk a very rapid discharge, which will vaporize heavy wire, throw small bits of molten metal, and generally bad, bad things. PLEASE do NOT mess with electrolytic dual layer capacitors unless you know what you are doing, and PLEASE see my write up on my spot welder design on this issue.

It is imperative that your unit be both properly fused and current limited, or you risk property loss, injury, or death. Proceed at your own risk.

description.text:
This is a model of the famous Pizza Planet rocket from various PIXAR movies. I designed it to be printed without infill in the main rocket body.
I will make a magnetic base soon and will rotate the parts to the proper oriantations when I get around to it.

Enjoy

EDIT: I have corrected the orientation of the parts so you wont need to rotate them in your slicer.

EDIT: I've added a second tail section with filleted fins for lower overhangs. If you're printing with poor part cooling or materials that don't handle overhangs well use this version.

EDIT: I made up several magnetic bases using four and six 1.26" by 0.7" neodymium magnets as per suggestion by ProfessorMajack. I made the holes for the magnets slightly oversized, (I may improve the fit later once i have the magnets to test with) the idea being that the magnets will be epoxied in place. The four magnet version will be more forgiving for curved surfaces, but will not provide as strong a hold. Note: I have yet to print or test either of the magnetic bases.

EDIT: I have uploaded an OBJ of the base upon request by ProfessorMajack. Note: the OBJ of the base is upside down and will need rotated before printing.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

0%

Notes:

I designed this to not require any infill in the main rocket body. the original plan was to install LEDs and a battery inside, but alas I got lazy and skipped that.
Mine is printed in PLA (will make a PETG one later) with 4 perimeters. I would not recommend printing with less than 3 perimeters.

Note: You will want to print in PETG if you intend to use it on a vehicle roof during the summer.

Note: The base will still require infill.

Note: Two M6x25 bolts are used to secure the rocket to the base. These are not required, but provide extra security.

Note: The alignment holes are made to fit 1/4 inch dowel rod.

Note: I have added a printable dowel for alignment.

description.text:
A friend of mine was asking for a lizard king wielding a large boar spear for his Pathfinder campaign. GameScape3D was kind enough to Creative Commons (Attribute/NonCommercial) a solid lizardman, and the rest of their models are good too.

I modified the spear to be a little more like a boar spear - it printed solid enough in PETG, didn't flex, but wasn't brittle. (Removed it from the base model, as I printed things separately.)

Removed the square base from the lizardman, made a "large-sized" D&D base, created a rock to fit the lizardman's feet in a more upright manner - Lizardman King is a large-sized creature, and now very upright. I changed the scale a little - the x/y axis was fine, but felt the King was a little short. Delicately stretched it a little on the z-axis.

The final product is a bit tall for a large Pathfinder model, even without standing on the rock - my buddy wanted something to terrify his players. ;)

TIBURON

The White Whistle belonging to The Lord/Sovereign of Dawn, Bondrewd the Novel from the anime/manga series "Made in Abyss".
Modelled in Maya Student version using various techniques, and converted to an stl with the desired orientation using 3D Builder.
It has a working whistle built into it, which is a modification of thing 1046 (link: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1046 ). All aesthetic modelling is completely original, based off images from the manga and screenshots from the anime.

For the best results, print it in the orientation it comes in with supports only from the build-plate (supports everywhere would add irremovable supports inside the whistle which would prevent it from making a sound), with a raft to guarantee that thumbnail prints correctly, and doesn't get squashed into the build plate. The example photos use a resolution of 0.15mm, 2 0.4mm skin layers, and 20% infill.

The air from the whistle exhausts between the thumbs.
Holes between the fingers allow the installation of a string or leather thong to wear it around your neck without interfering with the finish of the model, as an obvious ring would. This method also allows the knot to be discreetly hidden inside the whistle meaning that only a single continuous length of string ends up being visible on the outside.

The whistle is fairly loud, but requires a lot of breath to get it going due to the interior structure of the whistle. The tone is that of a standard sports whistle without the pea, and not the haunting note of a true White Whistle.

I hope you enjoy this thing I made.

comments.text:

title: Prusa I3 MK3 Parametric OpenSCAD Remix

description.text:
Originally I just wanted to change the position of the x axis idler, but the original Prusa OpenSCAD code makes it hard to change things because most dimensions are used directly. That's why I've decided to rewrite all parts, but driven by parameters stored in a single file.

OpenSCAD code here

Currently I've rewritten the following parts:

  • z-rod-bottom

    The Stepper is centered as in R2 of the original part. I also cut the front to make it easier to access the bolts behind the stepper. The chamfer on the outside ends flush with the frame.

  • z-rod-top

    The original part is a bit flexible left to right because of the cutout in the top and the narrow connections. Also the chamfer on the corner should end flush with the frame.

  • x-end-idler

    The idler is mounted 2 mm further upwards to make the belt parallel with the x axis.
    The cutout the idler is mounted in looks less "patchy". There are integrated bearing spacers in the bearing housing.

  • x-end-motor and x-tensioner

    I've added a tensioning mechanism with a bit more range and control.

  • y-motor-holder

    The stepper mount is adjustable, so you can move the stepper directly against the frame.

  • y-belt-idler

    Changed height of idler to make belt parallel with the y axis. Also there are added bridges to prevent the side mounted to the plate from getting convex when tightening the idler.

  • y-belt-holder

    Changed height of the belt slots to make the belt parallel with the y axis.

  • y-rod-holder

    No zip ties anymore. The part also employs a new technology called rounded corners.

  • einsy-base*

    No needed changes, but it is fully parametric now and the code is a lot shorter.

  • einsy-doors*

    The same as with einsy-base.

I haven't gotten around to rewrite the x-carriage but I've fixed the original stl's for a parallel x belt.

Parts marked with * have not been tested yet, but might work.
